title: How to feel about What's Going on by Marvin Gaye being Rolling Stones’ all time number 1 album - Quora

response.answer_text: Is it? Oh wow. Sgt Pepper used to be number one followed by Pet sounds then Revolver. What’s Going on is a great album and I’d highly recommend everyone check it out at least once. It could be the greatest album. It’s a subjective thing obviously and no matter which album is chosen most people will disagree due to the number of albums out there. I wonder if it got chosen this year because of the strange times we’re in at the moment. Some parts of the media said it was like 1968 this year because Black Lives matter, the protesting and the riots. What’s Going on was recorded in 1970 and came out in 1971 and I suppose an analogy could be drawn to the end of the 1960s with all the hope (and division) and then reality hit home in early 70s with Nixon and the Vietnam war still going and maybe a feeling that the world didn’t change as some people had hoped and the problems were still there with new problems added. Obama’s Hope and Change left a lot of people disappointed although he did do some great things. Then in came Trump who has been accused of abuses of power and who lies regularly. The times of Trump are a bit like Nixon in a way although there are some important differences as well. Maybe this point in time makes “What’s Going On” seem particularly relevant again. It’s always been a fantastic album but the way things are this year has probably pushed it up to number one.

The Rolling Stone ratings are based to a large degree on the influence an album had on other artists. To that point, I defer to their expertise. However, I don’t nearly care as much about that as how much enjoyment an album has given me. To that I say, “huh?” There are a few great songs on the album, but with all its choirs, violins, and preaching, I find it bit dated and sanctimonious. And, most of songs all sound too much alike. Bongos and falsetto singing on most of the songs? Greatest album of all-time? That’s nuts. If you want a mellow-ish party album with a similar vibe - Roxy Music’s Avalon is much better to my senses. Pink Floyd’s Dark Side of the Moon is less upbeat, but is far more magnificant.
